title-group.article-title: A new method for M-integral experimental evaluation

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory For Mechanical Structural Strength and Vibration, School of Aerospace, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, China
2School of Material Science & Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, China

author-notes.corresp: Hong Zuo, State Key Laboratory For Mechanical Structural Strength and Vibration, School of Aerospace, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, China. Email: zuohong@mail.xjtu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012. Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this article, the experimental measurement method of M-integral is investigated. Through the detailed analysis to the nondestructive evaluation method of J- and M-integrals suggested by King and Herrmann, it is found that the specimen geometry which they selected and the corresponding clamping mode in their test exists a conflict with the stress distribution assumption on the integral contour. The formulas they proposed cannot represent the selected specimen geometry and the related integral contours. To avoid this conflict, a new experimental measurement method and a simper specimen style is proposed in this study. According to the method, the M-integral is nondestructive evaluated experimentally through the new specimen and the new clamping mode.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Damage and its evolution in various kinds of inclusions embedded in material is the main factor, which leads to material and structure failure. Different parameters that can representatively describe and evaluate the effect of this damage on integrity of material and structure have been suggested and examined extensively by material and mechanical scientists in the last two decades (Abdul-Latif and Chadli 2007; Castagne et al., 2003; Flaceliere et al., 2007; Hammi et al., 2004; Ju and Ko, 2008; Ju et al., 2009; Ohata et al., 2010; Tang and Sih 2006; Saanouni et al., 1989). Within these parameters, the path-independent integrals, as a kind of inner variable parameter, received special attention.

The path-independent integrals have been investigated comprehensively by many researchers since the well-known J-integral was used within fracture mechanics (Eshelby 1951, 1970; Rice 1968a, b; Bergez, 1974; Freund, 1978; Knowles and Sternberg, 1972; Gunther, 1962; Budiansky and Rice, 1973; Bueckner, 1973; Herrmann, and Herrmann, 1981; King and Herrmann, 1981; Lin et al., 2005). Among these path-independent integrals, some of which are used to calculate the control parameters of a crack tips, but the others possess important physical interpretations potentially (Chen 2001a, b; Chen and Lu 2003, 2004; Hui and Chen 2010a, b; Hu and Chen 2011a, b). Thus, these path-independent integrals should be investigated in more details. As proposed by Herrmann and Herrmann (1981), L and M-integrals have a more relative suitable characteristic form in the expression of energy release rate for the crack. The key questions next are physical interpretations, calculation and measurement of the integrals.

In this article, the physical interpretations and the potential application of the M-integral are summarized first. After this, through analysis for the nondestructive evaluation method of path-independent M-integral proposed by King and Herrmann (1981), we found that the hypothesis, namely, the constant value of σyy stress distribution on the horizontal contours and identical with the far-field stress is not appropriated to the specimen geometry and fixture mode in the test. Through re-checking the integrand on the integral contour of the M-integral expression in details, a new method of nondestructive measurement for the M-integral of a simpler centered crack panel specimen is proposed.

sec.title: M-integral and its physical meaning
sec.p:
According to the definition of M-integral and J-integral (Budiansky and Rice, 1973; Gunther, 1962). The J-integral is expressed for a plane problem of an elastic body containing a crack as follows (Figure 1) (1)J=∫C(Wn1-Tkuk,1)ds Figure 1.
The definition of the J and M integral for a crack (contour C is for J-integral and contour c is for M-integral).

Where C is a contour surrounding the crack tip, W is the strain energy density, ui is the displacement vector, Tk is the traction vector acting on the outside a closed contour c.And the M-integral is defined as (2)M=∮c(Wxini-Tkuk,ixi)ds where c is now a closed curve anticlockwise surrounding the entire crack.

According to the definition of M-integral and J-integral (Budiansky and Rice, 1973; Knowles and Sternberg 1972), these integrals relate to the energy release rates of a crack enclosed by the integral contour. For example, as the integral contour C encloses one of the crack tips located along the x1-axis, the physical meaning of J-integral is considered as the energy release rates during the crack tip extension. On the other hand, when the closed integral contour c encloses the entire crack, then M-integral represents the energy release rates associated with the uniform crack self-similar expansion.

Since the location, orientation and shape of the enclosed cracks can be arbitrary, and the number of the cracks enclosed within the closed integral contour c is not confined in the definition of M-integral, it is reasonable to apply the M-integral to evaluate the damage or strength degradation of an overall body induced by a cloud of distributed defects rather than a single crack. Such a multi-defect damage mode could contain both a finite number of macro cracks or voids, and a densely distributed micro crack located and oriented randomly. Thus, using the energy parameters such as M-integral to describe the ‘global’ damaged state for a multi-defect damage is therefore, of practical importance. For example, it can be applied to evaluate the structure or material strength degradation resulted from the occurrence of micro cracks and voids located randomly in material, or other damage and failure formed locally in structure.

sec.title: The method proposed by King and Herrmann
sec.p: Generally speaking, the integrand of M-integral involves all the components of the stress and the rotation tensor in the (x1, x2) plane. It is difficult to measure M-integral experimentally. However, these integrands of M-integral can be reduced to a simple style and then can be measured through strain gages and displacement transducers experimentally, only for some special cases with a proper choice of the contour c in equation (2).

King and Herrmann (1981) performed an experimental test to evaluate the M-integral for three specimen styles (King and Herrmann, 1981): (i) A strip panel with an opening edge crack subjected to a remote uniaxial tension; (ii) a strip panel with an opening edge crack in which the wedge of the crack was forced; and (iii) the third specimen with a center crack subjected to a remote uniaxial tension shown in Figure 2. In our opinion, there exists a conflict in their works and this can produce wrong measured data of the M-integral. Figure 2.
Schematic of center cracked panel used for M-integral experiment (King and Herrmann, 1981).

Here, we are mainly concerned with the third case. In this case, the specimen selected is a centered crack rectangle panel with a thicker shoulder at upper and lower ends. The uniaxial tension is stressed on the two holes drilled in the center of the thicker shoulder parts (Figure 2). The integral contours chosen run counter-clockwise along the right and left vertical edges of the specimen and the upper and lower paths with a slight distance away from the horizontal shoulders, namely, the paths AB, BD, DE, and the right part contour path EA. Considering the symmetry of the specimen to the horizontal and vertical centerlines and the symmetry of the integral contour to the horizontal and vertical centerlines, we only need to calculate one quadrant of the specimen. Thus, the total M-integral is (3)M=4(MCD+MDE) where MCD and MDE are the integral term of M-integral contributed from the paths CD and DE, respectively. On the vertical path CD, the strain energy density W=E2ɛ222, and xini=b owing to the traction free on this edge, so (4)MCD=bE2∫0hɛ222dx2
On the path DE, the contribution to M is given by (5)MDE=∫b0{12E[σ112-σ222+2(1+υ)σ122]h+x1E(σ12σ11-υσ12σ22)-σ12u1, 2h+x1σ22u1, 2}dx1

King and Herrmann (1981) assumed that the stress along the loading direction σ22 is constant on the path DE. Since it is not clear that which term in the expression plays more important role on the integral, the each term in MDE is examined by the solution of an infinite cracked plate under remote uniaxial tension. Next, for a large rectangular path in an infinite plate, the M-integral is re-examined to substitute to that in the contour in the finite specimen. This induces that the contributions of terms containing σ11 and σ12 can be negligible, and if a quadratic variation with x is assumed for u2, the result for M is (6)MDE=hbσ2222E+4σ22b3[u2(0,h)-u2(b,h)]

Thus, the value of the M-integral for the panel with a centered crack under uniaxial tension is expressed by equations (3), (4) and (([A-z]))6). In the expression, the strain in the direction x2 along the path CD,ɛ22, can be measured experimentally through strain gages. The relative displacement 2u2(0,h) and 2u2(b,h) between AE and BD can be detected experimentally by displacement transducers.

sec.title: The new method for path-independent M-integral
sec.p: When we re-examine the measurement method of King and Herrmann (1981) in detail, we can find that there is a conflict between the specimen geometry they selected and the assumption they introduced during the simplification processes of formulas derived.

This conflict can be explained as follows: In general, once the thickness is different for a plane specimen, the total deformation of the specimen is mainly come from the thinner part. Especially, the deformation of the thicker part can be negligible and be thought as a rigid body in case the thickness of this part thicker enough, no matter how the loading holes or other defects embedded in the material. According to the method of King and Herrmann, in the specimen they selected, the thicker parts locate at the upper and lower ends (the shoulder). During deformation, the reasonable consequence should be that the deformation in these thicker parts can be ignored and thought as rigid. Thus, the movement of the two paths AB and DE along the loading direction should be separated parallel due to the symmetry of specimen to the vertical center line and the thicker shoulder. The displacement of the points on the paths AB or DE, which closer to the shoulder, should be keeps the same. Thus, the relative displacement 2u2(0,h) between points A and E, 2u2(b,h) between points B and D are identical during deformation. Consequently, the second term in equation (6) vanishes. Naturally, these relative displacement values don’t need to measure using any displacement transducers during measurement.

Following this consideration, let’s focus our attention to the stress distribution on the upper and lower paths of the integral contour. According to the specimen of King and Herrmann, the constant stress σ22 or strain ɛ22 on the paths AB and DE cannot be deduced. In fact, the strain ɛ22 or the stress σ22 along the two paths AB and DE are changed owing to the centered crack embedded in the specimen. Therefore, the first term in equation (6) cannot be determined through the method they proposed experimentally.

According to the above analysis, the assumptions of King and Herrmann related to the constant value of σ22 and the different value of relative displacements 2u2(0,h) and 2u2(b,h) are conflict for their specimen (Figure 2). This conflict induces a mistake measure results for the M-integral according to the formula (6) using the specimen geometry (Figure 2) they suggested under uniform tension.

In the following, we will propose a new method for nondestructive measure of the M-integral through adopting a simpler specimen and corresponding clamping mode under uniform tension (Figure 3). The integral contour selected is similarly with that of King and Herrmann. The contour chosen runs along the right and left vertical edges of the specimen, but the upper and lower boundaries AB or DE are selected near the upper and lower clamping zones with an equal distance away from the central crack. Since the symmetry of the specimen geometry to the coordinate x1 and x2-axis originated at the specimen center, it only needs to consider the upper-right quadrant. Thus, equations (3) and (4) could be also used in this condition, but equation (6) needs to be re-examined. Figure 3.
The simple specimen geometry and fixture mode.
Let us start from the expanded form of equation (2) (7)M=∮c[W(x1n1+x2n2)-(T1∂u1∂x1x1+T1∂u1∂x2x2+T2∂u2∂x1x1+T2∂u2∂x2x2)]ds
Where W is the strain energy density and Tk=σjknj

From equation (3), we can examine the value of M-integral in paths CD and DE, respectively. Here MCD is the same as that in equation (4). However, in path DE (Figure 3), the most parameters in the integrand of Equation (7) can be determined due to the intentionally chosen contour. Thus, in path DE, x2=h, n1=0, n2=1. Then, T1=0, ∂u2∂x1=0 and T2=σ22n2=σ22=Eɛ22. It follows (8)MDE=∫b0(12Ehɛ222-Ehɛ222)dx1=Eh2∫0bɛ222dx1 which leads the M-integral in total contour, (9)M=4(bE2∫0hɛ222dx2+Eh2∫0bɛ222dx1)

It can be found from equation (9) that the strain along the direction x2, ɛ22 is the only unknown parameter which needs to be measured both on the path CD and on the path DE. The strain ɛ22 can be measured using several strain gages placed along each of the vertical edge CD and horizontal path DE experimentally.

sec.title: Experimental verification
sec.p:
The experimental verification is carried out to measure the M-integral around single center crack in a specimen suggested by us. In the test, the specimen material is selected as PMMA. The specimen geometry is illustrated as in Figure 3 with a size of length of 150 mm, width of 30 mm, and thickness of 3 mm. The length of centered crack is 8 mm. The crack tip is prepared to obtain a kind of mathematical sharp crack tip by high-frequency fatigue tension test. Five strain gages are mounted on the vertical edge DC and two strain gages are mounted on the transverse edge ED to measure the strain along the vertical direction as shown in Figure 4. The specimen is placed in a hydraulic displacement controlled testing machine (MTS-858 Mini Bionixell) (Figure 5) and loaded to a tension of 9000 N. The experimental measured value for M-integral is 1.79 N while the theoretical value for M is approximately (10)M=2aJR=2aKI2E=1.81N Figure 4.
The specimen and the distribution of strain gage.
Figure 5.
The specimen and the test rig (MTS-858 Mini Bionixell).
This indicates that the experimental measured value agrees well with the theoretical value.

We also examine the measured value of ɛ22 at point D and E, and the strain on the loading direction at point D and E are 0.2335 and 0.2123, respectively. This reveals that there indeed exists an evident difference between the strain values at the two measured point.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The experimental nondestructive evaluation method for the conservation integral (M-integral) is re-studied in this article. It has been shown that the M-integral can be nondestructive measured simply through measuring the strain ɛ22 on the partial contour for the studied specimen and intentionally chosen integral contours. Compared with the method proposed by King and Herrmann (1981), our method does not need to measure the displacements between upper and lower opposite points and also does not need complicated additional deduction. The new method is simpler and easy to implement than the method of King and Herrmann.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the China National Natural Science Foundation (10932007, 11172228).
